qas.question: When did Russian language spread to the peasants?
Who spoke Russian before the 20th century?

answers.text: the upper noble classes and urban population

qas.question: When did the Soviets establish required education?
What nonstandard feature does Southern Russian use?
When did the Soviet government begin only speaking fricative?
What kind of education system was used to teach the history of the noble classes to peasants?
Who was responsible for formalizing colloquial speech?
What nonstandard feature do the noble classes have?

plausible_answers.text: upper noble classes and urban population

qas.question: In the mid 20th century what  group was the only one that used colloquial speech?

context: Until <a0_0>the 20th century<a0_0/>, the language's spoken form was the language of only <a1_0>the <b8_0>upper noble classes and urban population<b8_0/><a1_0/>, as Russian peasants from the countryside continued to speak in their own dialects. <b4_0>By <a2_0>the mid-20th century<b4_0/><a2_0/>, such dialects were forced out with the introduction of the <b5_0>compulsory<b5_0/> education system that was established by <b6_0>the Soviet government<b6_0/>. Despite the formalization of Standard Russian, some nonstandard dialectal features (such as <a3_0><b7_0>fricative<b7_0/><a3_0/> [ɣ] in Southern Russian dialects) are still observed in colloquial speech.
